question.title: JOGL graphic exception
question.body:
I am currently working on a JOGL project in Eclipse, but I’m facing an issue when running my code. The program throws an exception related to the graphics configuration: com.jogamp.opengl.GLException: Unable to determine GraphicsConfiguration: WindowsWGLGraphicsConfiguration. I have already included the necessary JOGL libraries, such as jogl-all.jar and gluegen-rt.jar, and placed the corresponding native .dll files in what I believe to be the correct locations. Despite this, the program fails to initialize the OpenGL context. I’ve checked my system's OpenGL support using OpenGL Extensions Viewer, and my graphics drivers are up to date. I even tried adding compatibility settings like disabling the OpenGL core profile, but the error persists. I suspect it might be related to either a misconfiguration of the JOGL libraries in Eclipse or an incompatibility between JOGL and my Java version (I’m using Java 17). I’m looking for guidance on how to ensure the .dll files are correctly recognized and the libraries are properly configured.

Exception in thread "main" com.jogamp.opengl.GLException: Unable to determine GraphicsConfiguration: WindowsWGLGraphicsConfiguration[DefaultGraphicsScreen[WindowsGraphicsDevice[type .windows, connection decon, unitID 0, handle 0x0, owner false, NullToolkitLock[obj 0x74a5cd97]], idx 0]

the code :

package fourth;

public static void main(String[] args) {
    // Activates JOGL debug logs
    System.setProperty("jogl.debug.NativeLibrary", "true");
    System.setProperty("jogl.debug.GLProfile", "true");
    System.setProperty("jogl.disable.openglcore", "true"); // Forces the compatibility

    GLProfile profile = GLProfile.get(GLProfile.GL2);
    GLCapabilities capabilities = new GLCapabilities(profile);

    GLCanvas canvas = new GLCanvas(capabilities);
    canvas.addGLEventListener(new Check());

    JFrame frame = new JFrame("JOGL Test - Colored triangle");
    frame.setSize(800, 600);
    frame.add(canvas);
    frame.setVisible(true);
    frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
}

I tried many things like open gel viewers, check drivers
